Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Raman spectra and an extended-spectrum region graphic insert and (b) 31P MAS-NMR spectra of TPA-catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Product distribution during waste tire pyrolysis at different temperatures and (b) reaction pathways. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Catalytic waste tire pyrolysis was performed at 400°C. The synthesis of catalysts for upgrading waste tire pyrolysis oils (TPO) into marketable products such as fuels, solvents or fine chemicals is a major challenge. Herein, the effect of CeO2, SiO2, and TiO2 catalysts containing tunsgtophosphoric acid (TPA) on the selectivity to aromatics (benzene, toluene, and xylenes viz. BTXs) and p-cymene was studied for the first time. Modifying TiO2 with 1% and 10% TPA allowed modulating the oxide's acidity, resulting in a ratio of Lewis acid sites and strong Brønsted acid sites that favored the target compound formation. The 1%TPA catalyst enhanced the p-cymene production (Sp-cymene = 56.3%). In contrast, 10%TPA promoted BTX formation (SBTX= 26%) over p-cymene (Sp-cymene = 6.5%) due to its greater content of Brønsted acid sites. The selectivity of SiO2 and CeO2-based catalysts to these aromatic compounds was in the same order as the uncatalyzed reaction. The p-cymene is mainly formed from secondary reactions of isomerization of limonene to other terpenes (terpinolene, α-terpinene, and γ-terpinene) and the subsequent ring dehydrogenation with an activation energy of 62.3 kJ mol−1. The BTXs were kinetically favored on 10%TPATi catalyst with an Ea = 112 kJ mol−1. The study was performed in a fixed bed Pyr-GC/MS system under kinetically controlled regime. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Waste tires Catalytic pyrolysis Tungstophosphoric acid Support effect Abbreviations TPO tire pyrolysis oils TPA tunsgtophosphoric acid BTXs benzene, toluene, and xylenes WTP waste tire pyrolysis HPAs heteropolyacids BAS Brønsted acid sites LAS Lewis acid sites ICP-OES inductively coupled plasma - optical emission spectrometry BET Brunauer-Emmett-Teller BJH Barrett-Joyner-Halenda ATR attenuated total reflectance FTIR Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy 31P MAS NMR 31P magic angle spinning-nuclear magnetic resonance Pyr-GC/MS micro-pyrolysis reactor coupled to chromatograph/mass spectrometer TGA thermogravimetric analysis DTG derivative thermogravimetry IR polyisoprene rubber SBR styrene-butadiene rubber BR polybutadiene rubber Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Pyrolysis has emerged as a promising technology to dispose of and/or valorize waste tires into fuels, chemicals, and other added-value products [1]. During pyrolysis, the polymeric fraction of tires (natural rubber and synthetic rubbers: polybutadiene and styrene-butadiene) is converted into three major fractions: a liquid (35%-65%, TPO), a solid (12%-45%, recovered carbon black), and a gas (10%-35%, tire pyrolysis gas). In particular, the TPO is a mix of benzene, toluene, mixed xylenes, ethylbenzene, isoprene, D,L-limonene, p-cymene, alkenes, and cycloalkenes, many of which are attractive to the industry as solvents, fuel additives or synthetic platforms. However, this multicomponent character makes the TPO susceptible to the change of its chemical, physical (viscosity, density, total acid number) and multiphase structure properties. This instability of TPO is called “aging”, and it makes challenging the storage, handling, transportation, upgrading and application of this liquid. The aging is ascribed to a reactive process (e.g., polymerization, esterification, dimerization reactions) taking place under acidic conditions and catalyzed by the presence of nanoparticles of carbon black. One plausible strategy for reducing the effects of aging, stabilize the TPO and facilitate its valorization is its use as a crude oil blending in existing refineries. However, this alternative requires for the creation of new logistic chains, to modify legal regulations, and creating validated standards. Other upgrading strategies based on the optimization of reaction conditions and the use of heterogeneous catalysts have been extensively explored as was confirmed in a recently published review [2]. Although the reaction conditions (temperature, contact time, heating rate, pressure, etc.) are very relevant for tailoring the product distribution during pyrolysis, there is a chemical boundary where the use of catalysts is mandatory. Such a boundary condition is defined by the intended "upgrading," and in many cases, it involves the production of particular identities such as BTXs, D,L-limonene, and, more recently, p-cymene [3–6]. The formation of single-ring aromatic compounds from catalytic pyrolysis of waste tires over Y-zeolite and ZMS-5 zeolite was first reported by Williams et al. [7]. Williams's study evidenced that Y-zeolite with a lower Si/Al ratio, thus with a higher surface acidity, preferentially leads to the formation of BTXs and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. Since then, numerous studies have focused on increasing monoaromatic production via waste tire pyrolysis (WTP) by using different catalysts: (i) zeolites [8–14], (ii) heteropolyacids [6,15]), (iii) supported metal catalysts (Pd, Ni, Co)[4], and (iv) bifunctional catalysts (Cu, Ru, Ni, Pt/zeolite; Pd, Pt, Au/titanate nanotubes; Pt, Pd/halloysites) [3,5,16,17]. All these studies agree that acidity and/or the presence of metal sites are critical for promoting secondary reactions of dehydrogenation, isomerization, and aromatization that could favor the production of BTXs. Despite zeolites having shown excellent results due to their well-known acidity, some reports indicate that the density and strength of their acid sites would favor the formation of PAHs, leading to a possible catalyst deactivation [16,18–21]. In recent years several works have addressed this problem by synthesizing acid catalysts that retain the activity of zeolites for producing aromatics and hinder the formation of PAHs [3,5]. These works confirmed that bifunctional catalysts based on noble metals supported on acidic materials favor dehydrogenation and isomerization reactions, leading to an increment in the selectivity of aromatic compounds such as p-cymene and BTXs. However, besides BTXs and p-cymene, the tire pyrolysis oils obtained with those catalysts also contains considerable proportions of D,L-limonene, isoprene, and some olefins. Accordingly, further efforts are required to increase the selectivity of targeted products by obtaining more site-specific catalysts and understanding their role in the reaction mechanisms. Heteropolyacids (HPAs) could be an interesting and little-explored alternative for these reactions, considering their widely known acidic characteristics and the possibility of tailoring the density and nature of the acid sites. HPAs correspond to a class of nanosized transition metal-oxygen clusters, which can be classified by the unit "parent" polycation [22]. The most common structures of HPAs used in several catalytic reactions are the Kegging (XM12O40 n−), Wells-Dawson (X2M18O62 n−), Lindquist (M6O19 n−), and Anderson (XM6O24 n−). The Keggin anion contains an atom that can be P or Si as the center of an XO4 n− unit; on each corner of this central tetrahedron, there are three WO6 octahedra bonded, sharing corners and sides (W3O13). This arrangement constitutes the primary structure, while the three-dimensional arrangement of these units containing counter cations (e.g., H+aq) and crystallization water corresponds to the secondary structure. The latter structure is responsible for Brønsted acid sites (BAS) exhibited by HPAs, whose strength and density depend on their degree of hydration. The tunsgtophosphoric acid (Keggin structure H3PW12O40, TPA) is an HPA with high thermal stability; thus it has more potential for its application in pyrolysis processes [23–25]. Despite having several advantages, the HPAs commonly have low specific surface areas (∼ 1−5 m2 g−1), which in many cases limit their applications in gas-solid heterogeneous catalysis. A plausible solution to this issue is to disperse the acid on supports that provide surface area and thermal stabilities, facilitating the generation of new acidic functionalities in the composite material. In this context, acid center content, nature, and strength can be controlled by the structure and composition of heteropolyanions, thermal pretreatment, degree of hydration, type of support, and amount loaded [23]. This latter parameter shows a significant dependence on acidity. At a low loading level of heteropoly acid (< 5 wt.%), a strong acidity is not observed, which gradually increases upon an increase in the loading level, reaching a plateau between 15 and 50 wt.% load and then declining above 50 wt.% [26]. Even though catalysts based on HPAs have been successfully employed in several reactions as efficient supported acid catalysts [27,28,37,29–36], very few studies of their use in WTP have been reported [6,15]. Recently, Tavera-Ruiz et al.[6] aimed to enhance the BTX yield in TPO by using three heteropoly acids with different acidity (H3PW12O40, H3PMo12O40, and H4PMo11VO40) supported over commercial silica (CARiACTQ-10). However, the authors found no significant difference in the concentration of BTXs among the catalysts evaluated. On the contrary, they demonstrated the higher number of Lewis acid sites (LAS), the higher the concentration of p-cymene in the detected products. In a later study, the same group evaluated four types of HPAs (H3PW12O40, H3PMo12O40, H4SiW12O40, and H4PMo11VO40) supported on Q-10, SBA-15, MCM-41, and KIT-6 and demonstrated that limonene transformation pathways are affected by the nature of the HPA and the supports [15]. In particular, the catalysts with weak acidity and the largest number of LAS mostly promoted the isomerization/dehydrogenation of limonene, leading to p-cymene, while those with the highest total acidity and greatest number of LAS favored disproportionation activity leading to menthenes and p-cymene. These results indicate that in addition to the density and strength of the acid sites, their nature (BAS and LAS) could influence the reaction selectivity. Although these studies shed light on the role of HPA acidity in product distribution from WTP, a comprehensive analysis describing the relationship between the nature of acid sites, reaction pathways, and product distribution for this reaction system is still pending. Therefore, the present work aims to inspect the role of tunsgtophosphoric acid-modified CeO2, TiO2, and SiO2 oxides as catalysts for producing single-ring aromatics (BTXs and p-cymene) from WTP. The major questions we intend to answer are: Is the aromatic selectivity affected by the nature of the HPA-containing material? Furthermore, is there a correlation between catalytic activity and the amount, strength, and nature of acid sites in the catalysts? Finally, how do HPA-modified catalysts affect the secondary reaction pathways in the WTP, and what are the kinetic implications for relevant reaction steps? 2 Experimental 2.1 Feedstock and chemical reagents Waste tires were acquired as granules, crushed, and sieved into particle sizes between 180 and 300 μm. All chemical reagents, supports, and pure elastomers (cis-1,4-polyisoprene, cis-polybutadiene, and styrene- butadiene) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Chile): DL-limonene (≥95.0%, CAS Number 138-86-3), benzene (≥99.9%, CAS Number 71-43-2), o-xylene (≥99.0%, CAS Number 95-47-6), m-xylene (≥99.5%, CAS Number 108-38-3), p-xylene (≥99.5%, CAS Number 106-42-3), toluene (≥99.9%, CAS Number 108-88-3), p-cymene (≥99.5%, CAS Number 99-87-6), TiO2 (99.8%, CAS Number 1317-70-0), CeO2 (> 99.0%, CAS Number 1306-38-3), and H3PW12O40 ·23H2O (99.99%, CAS Number 12501-23-4). The SiO2 was supplied by Alfa Aesar (> 99.0%, CAS Number 44740). 2.2 Raw material characterization Elemental composition of the raw material (waste tire) was measured in a Leco CHNS 628 elemental analyzer (ASTM D5291 Standard method). The proximate analyses for moisture content, volatile matter, ash content and fixed carbon was performed in a muffle furnace by following the ASTM D3172 Standard method (Thermo Scientific F6020C). Meanwhile, the composition of inorganic elements was determined by inductively coupled plasma - optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) using a PerkinElmer Optima 7000 DV ICP-OES series instrument (UNE En 15290 and 15297 Method). The thermogravimetric analyses of tire decomposition were performed in a Shimadzu TGA 50 Thermobalance. Experiments were carried out under He flow (50 mL min−1) using ∼1 mg of the sample and at a temperature range from 20°C to 650°C at a heating rate of 30°C min−1. 2.3 Synthesis and characterization of catalysts Catalysts were prepared by impregnating the supports (CeO2, TiO2, and SiO2) with absolute ethanol (9 mL) containing 0.03 g (2.97 g of support) and 0.3 g (2.7 g of support) of commercial H3PW12O40 to obtain 1 and 10 wt.% of TPA, respectively. During preparation, each ethanolic suspension was stirred at room temperature for 24 h, and then was dried at 80°C overnight. Finally, the solids were calcined at 500°C for 2 h with a heating rate of 5°C min−1. The catalysts were named as xTPATi, xTPASi, and xTPACe, where x = 1 or 10 and Ti = TiO2, Si = SiO2, and Ce = CeO2. The nominal composition was used as TPA final load since the preparation method does not lead to a significant loss of TPA during synthesis, as demonstrated in previous work [38]. The specific surface area, pore volume and pore size distributions were calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively, through N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms recorded at −196°C in Micromeritics Tristar II apparatus. Attenuated total reflectance (ATR)-Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were collected using a Nicolet iS20 instrument (Thermo Fisher, USA) equipped with an ATR accessory (Quest, Specac) with a Ge crystal having a penetration depth of approximately 0.65 μm. The spectra were recorded using 2 mg of the sample, ranging from 4000 to 400 cm−1 with 32 scans and at 4 cm−1 resolution. Raman spectra were collected using a Raman triple grating spectrometer (HORIBA Jobin Yvon T64000) equipped with a liquid N2-cooled CCD detector. A laser of 647.1 nm Kr line was used, and the spectral resolution was 4 cm−1. The 31P magic angle spinning-nuclear magnetic resonance (31P MAS-NMR) spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance II equipment using the CPA/MAS 1H-31P technique. For the measurement, a sample holder of 4 mm in diameter and 10 mm in height was employed, using 5 ms pulses, and a repetition time of 4 s at a frequency of 121.496 MHz. The spin rate was 8 kHz, and several hundred pulse responses were collected. Phosphoric acid 85% was used as an external reference. The nature of acid sites was studied by pyridine adsorption/desorption monitored via FTIR spectroscopy in a Jasco FTIR 5300 spectrometer. Self-supported disks pressing between 20 and 85 mg of material were prepared and outgassed in a cell with CaF2 windows at 400°C and 10-4 Torr for 5 h before pyridine adsorption. Subsequently, the pellets were contacted with pyridine (3 Torr) at room temperature for 12 h. Then, the probe molecule was desorbed for 1 h at 10−4 Torr at 250, 350, and 400°C and IR spectra of the adsorbed pyridine are recorded after each heat treatment. The quantification of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites expressed in units of μmol g−1 (μmol of pyridine per gram of catalyst) was determined using the IR bands at 1545 cm−1 and 1455 cm−1 respectively. For each IR band at the different temperatures, the amount of acid sites was established based on Beer's law as reported by Emeis et al. [39]. The point of zero charge (PZC) of the supports (SiO2, TiO2, and CeO2) was measured using a Stabino ZETA-potential analyzer (Microtrac Ltd.) at a constant temperature of 18°C. In a typical analysis, 20 mg of support (<75µm) was dispersed in 100 mL of ultrapure water by mixing at 600 rpm for 30 min. Thereafter, 10 mL of supernatant was transferred to the Z-potential device for dynamic titration using 1 M HCl or KOH solutions. 2.4 Analytical pyrolysis experiments The fast pyrolysis experiments, with and without catalysts, were performed in an analytical micro-pyrolysis reactor (CDS5200, CDS Analytical) connected to a gas chromatograph (GC Perkin Elmer Clarus 590) coupled to mass spectrometer (MS Perkin Elmer SQ-8T) (Py-GC/MS). Typically, 1 ± 0.1 mg of sample (waste tire, cis-1,4-polyisoprene, cis-polybutadiene, and styrene-butadiene) was placed in a quartz tube reactor having a length of 2 cm and internal diameter of 2 mm. A catalyst:feedstock ratio of 2:1 was used in catalyzed reactions. Based on our previous studies, the experiments were performed between 400 and 500°C using a heating rate of 2°C ms–1 and high-purity He (99.996%, BOC) as carrier gas. Samples were kept at the desired pyrolysis temperature for 6, 12, 20, 30 and 40 s depending on the experiment. Products reaction were transfer to analysis section (GC/MS) by transfer line kept at 280°C. An Elite 1701 column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) separated these products by heating from 45 to 280°C at 2.5°C min–1. The compounds were identified by their mass spectra, matching them to the NIST MS library. The product distribution was determined as the relative peak area ( A r e a c o m p o u n d ( i ) / A r e a a l l i d e n t i f i e d c o m p o u n d s ) . The yields (Eq. (1)) were determined by product quantification using calibration curves (R2> 0.995) prepared for each analytical standard, following the method reported by Klemetsrud et al. [40]. (1) Y i e l d o f c o m p o u n d ( i ) = m a s s o f c o m p o u n d ( i ) ( i n i t i a l m a s s o f w a s t e t i r e * X W T ) × 100 where XWT is the conversion in each case, i = benzene, toluene, xylene, p-cymene. 2.5 Kinetic analysis Here, the procedure reported by Klinger et al. [41] and Klemetsrud et al. [40] was applied to studying fast pyrolysis kinetics in a Py-GC/MS system. The model was implemented to elucidate kinetic parameters associated with the solid decomposition and the evolution of target species (BTX and p-cymene) at different temperatures and pyrolysis times. Although this is not a mechanism-ruled analysis, it provides valuable information (i.e., activation energies) for interpreting the effect of catalysts in waste tire pyrolysis and its correlation to specific compound formation. The rate expression (Eq. (2)) thus includes a term related to pyrolysis temperature (K) and the kinetic expression (f(α)). (2) d ( α ) d t = K f ( α ) For generating conversion vs. time curves, the pyrolysis was performed at six different residence times (2, 6, 12, 20, 30, and 40 s). Then the conversion of waste tire was calculated by the fractional weight difference between the initial tire mass (mo) and the mass remaining after pyrolysis (mt) corrected as dry-ash-free values (Eq. (3)). (3) α = ( m 0 − m t ) m 0 Inversely, for target compounds, the conversion was related to the volatiles produced at any given time (Vi, i = BTX, p-cymene) versus the total amount of volatiles produced (Vt). This term is referred to as normalized yield along this manuscript. (4) α = V i / V t The K values at different temperatures are assumed to follow an Arrhenius-type function (Eq. (5)), where (Ea) is the activation energy and k 0 is the pre-exponential factor. (5) K = k 0 × e x p ( − E a / R T ) The model was implanted in MATHLAB® for estimating constants of several kinetic expressions (Table 1 ) via a FOR block and by minimizing the following error function: (6) e r r o r = ∑ i ( α i , m o d e l * − α i , e x p * ) 2 , i = s o l i d , B T X , p − c y m e n e The differential equations were solved by using the ode45 subroutine, and the optimization of the parameters was achieved by the least-squares function (lsqr). The fitting quality was evaluated by the well-known coefficient of determination between experimental and predicted values (R2). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Table 2 shows the textural characteristics of catalysts and supports. The results suggest that specific surface areas (SBET) of supports were not significantly affected by the deposition of TPA, and the catalysts follow the same order of area as their original supporting materials (SiO2> TiO2> CeO2). This could be explained by the estimated theoretical coverage, which only exceeds the monolayer limit for CeO2 with a 10% TPA. In fact, this percentage of TPA in CeO2 presumably produced the blockage of pores in the support, leading to a 54% decrease in the average pore volume and 30% in surface area. All the N2 isotherms of catalysts can be classified as Type IV according to the IUPAC, which are characteristic of mesoporous materials (Fig. S1). Catalysts were characterized by several techniques such as FTIR (Fig. 1 ), Raman (Fig. 2 a), and MAS 31P NMR (Fig. 2b) to confirm the preservation of the Keggin structure after its synthesis. The IR spectrum of unsupported commercial TPA showed five vibration bands at 1081, 982, 900, 793 and 595 cm−1 associated with skeletal vibration of the Keggin anion (Fig. S2) [43]. The first two bands located at 1081 cm−1 and 982 cm−1 are ascribed to the P-O stretching and W=O asymmetric stretching modes, respectively, while the bands at 900 cm−1 and 793 cm−1 are related to two types of asymmetric stretching of W-O-W units. The last band to 595 cm-1 has been associated with the bending vibration of O–P–O units [44]. For TPATi catalysts, the typical stretching bands for P-O and W=O were the only signals observed since the TiO2 exhibits an intense and broad vibration band from Ti-O-Ti bonds below 900 cm−1 that overlaps with the other TPA bands (Fig. 1). A similar overlapping occurred for TPASi catalysts between 700 and 1100 cm−1 since SiO2 vibration bands for asymmetric and symmetric Si-O-Si stretching are located within this range. However, for these catalysts, it was possible to identify the bands corresponding to Keggin species around 805 and 973 cm−1. These results confirmed that the Kegging structure had been maintained in the TPA composite with TiO2 and SiO2. Furthermore, all vibration frequencies appeared slightly shifted to lower wavelengths, suggesting the existence of interaction of the heteropoly acid with the support surface. Nevertheless, for TPACe, the picture was quite different as it was not possible to confirm the presence of the heteropoly acid-related structure signals. On the other hand, the typical Raman spectrum for the Keggin skeleton, with intense bands of W=O stretching at ca. 990 and 1005 cm−1 , was not observed in any of the catalysts. However, on CeO2, in addition to the intense band at 458 cm−1 associated with F2g modes of the cubic fluorite structure, three bands commonly ascribed to bulk WO3 were identified (Fig. 2a) [45]. The crystalline WO3 structure presents two bands assigned to W-O-W stretching frequencies (ca. 805 and 706 cm−1) and another attributed to W-O-W bending mode (ca. 273 cm−1). In Ce-catalyst, as can be seen in the insert of Fig. 2, these bands were plainly identified, suggesting the decomposition of Keggin structure after the immobilization process over CeO2-support. The 31P MAS-NMR spectra of the unsupported TPA and TPA-loaded catalysts are presented in Figs. S2 and 2b, respectively. The pure heteropoly acid gave only one signal at about δ∼15 ppm (Fig. S2b). Meanwhile, for catalysts, only the 10TPATi catalyst displays strong peaks associated with TPA (Fig. 2b). Two sharp peaks at 14.8 and 13.9 ppm can be detected on this spectrum. The first peak could be assigned to H3PW12040 with slight interaction with the support surface [46], while the second one could be attributed to surface species, such as [ T i − O H 2 + ] [ H 2 P W 12 O 40 − ] , which can be generated by electrostatic interaction between protonated Ti-OH and TPA [47]. However, it is also necessary to consider the formation of Ti-O-W bonds due to water elimination during thermal treatment that gives rise to a chemical shift in this zone. In addition, the broad band ranging from -3 to -13 ppm may be assigned to the presence of dimeric [P2W21O71]6− and lacunar [PW11O39]7− species [43]. In contrast, in the NMR spectrum of 10TPASi catalyst, a broad band surrounding a weak peak at 15.6 ppm was only observed, while the 10TPACe-catalyst showed only broad resonances with no fine peak. These results indicate a breakdown of the highly symmetric HPA Keggin unit, as was also reported by Dufaud et al. [48]. Clearly, a greater structure affectation was observed over the Ce-based catalyst. For catalysts containing 1% TPA, it was not possible to observe signals corresponding to TPA by 31P MAS-NMR due to the low concentration of the heteropoly acid. Concerning the nature, strength and content of the acid sites, these were identified through adsorption-desorption of pyridine followed by FT-IR spectroscopy (Table 3 and Fig. S3). Typically, the FTIR spectra present six bands; the signals at 1545 and 1635 cm−1 are commonly associated with protonate pyridine bonded to Brønsted acid sites, while those found at 1445, 1575, and 1610 cm−1 are ascribed to pyridine coordinately bonded to the Lewis acid sites. The band at 1490 cm−1 can be related to both acid sites. Then, the number of acid sites was calculated by using the integral of the peaks for the vibration bands at 1445 cm−1 for LAS and 1545 cm−1 for BAS. In addition, the FTIR spectra of pyridine were recorded at different desorption temperatures to evaluate the acid strength of the sites. A classification according to the temperature-related position of peaks was established as follows: strong sites (T > 400 °C), medium strength sites (350 < T < 400 °C), and weak sites (250 < T < 350 °C). The highest content of LAS (strong, medium, and weak) was found in the 1TPATi catalyst, while the 10TPATi showed the highest amount of strong BAS. The concentration of the BAS decreased in the following order for prepared catalysts: 10TPATi >1TPATi >>> 10TPASi ≈ 1TPASi ≈ 1TPACe > 10TPACe. Meanwhile, for the LAS content the order was rather different: 1TPATi > 10TPATi > 10TPACe >>> 1TPASi > 1TPACe > 10TPASi. The TiO2 support exhibited the highest content of LAS, mainly weak LAS. Finally, the largest BAS and LAS content was detected in the TiO2-catalysts, which can be explained based on a lower decomposition of TPA in these catalysts, leading to the preservation of acid sites coming from the heteropoly acid (typically Brønsted) and support (mainly Lewis). The previous characterization shows that although the content of TPA immobilized on the three supports was the same, both the acid strength and the content of acid sites changed with the nature of the support. Similar results have been found in other studies, where the support strongly influenced catalyst characteristics and catalytic activity [49–52]. The detected differences were related to the interaction between the heteropoly acid and the support, which affects the hydration degree (acidity) and HPA structure stability. In fact, a strong interaction with the HPA species could induce its decomposition and/or structure distortion resulting in lower acidity, as was found here for SiO2 and CeO2 [22,37,50]. Marci et al. [50] attributed this decomposition to the interaction between the acid-basic properties of the support and the HPA. These authors suggested that the supports with higher PZC values (> 8), such as Al2O3, induced a higher HPA degradation. Moreover, the interaction may also depend on the HPA loading, as was outlined by Misono et al. [23] for SiO2 support, who witnessed a partial decomposition of the HPA at loadings below 5%, owing to a stronger interaction with surface silanol groups. However, some studies have reported using HPA at low loadings with good catalytic results. For example, Honda et al. [30] indicated that CeO2 modification with 1%TPA improved the initiation efficiency during bulk ring-opening polymerization of trimethylene carbonate. This result was related to an increase in the number of strong acid sites on CeO2. In the present paper, the supports that showed a lower Keggin structure stability presented a very low PZC (around 2.5 for CeO2 and SiO2), while the TiO2 exhibited a PZC of 6.0. Very low PZC values would be associated with higher deprotonation capacity. Finally, from these results, it was demonstrated that for TiO2-supported catalysts, the Keggin structure of the HPA was more preserved, while for SiO2 and CeO2, the FTIR, Raman, MAS 31P MAS NMR, and FTIR spectra of pyridine indicate the presence of decomposition with implications on the acid properties. Moreover, on CeO2, the WO3 species formation confirmed that the TPA suffers a higher degree of decomposition on this support. This decomposition is related to the interaction between TPA and support. In the case of SiO2 has been widely reported that the protons in H3PW12O40 react with silanol groups by an acid-base mechanism on impregnation leading to the formation of [Si–OH2]+ surface species. Upon heat treatment, the elimination of water in these groups involves a direct bonding of the polyanion to the support [46,53], leading to the loss of acid sites of the catalyst. This same mechanism has been suggested for CeO2 [5] and TiO2 [47]; however, the higher basic character of CeO2 led to higher TPA decomposition, as confirmed by the characterization. With these results in hand, micropyrolysis experiments were carried out to confirm the effects of these chemical and structural changes on the pyrolysis reactions. 3.2 Characterization of waste tires Proximate analysis of waste tire samples showed an organic carbon content (volatile matter) of around 58.8% (Table 4 ), which is susceptible to decomposition, while the fixed carbon (nonvolatile) was about 30.2%. The elemental analysis displayed the presence of nitrogen (0.47 ± 0.03%) and sulfur (1.48 ± 0.06%), which are used as vulcanizing agents. The low concentrations of metallic elements such as aluminum, iron, calcium, potassium, and sodium in the raw material may rule out their participation in the pyrolysis reactions. The TGA and DTG profiles of waste tire followed at 30°C min−1 are presented in Fig. S4. The first DTG peak, around 230°C, was attributed to the decomposition of the volatile matter, such as plasticizers and additives, used in tire fabrication. Moreover, the highest mass loss rate of waste tire was centered at 380°C, with a small shoulder at about 450°C, assigned, respectively, to the decomposition of polyisoprene rubber (IR) and styrene-butadiene rubber (SBR). The last two observed events, between 500 and 600°C, are associated with thermal degradation of more stable polymeric structures deriving from polybutadiene rubber (BR) and SBR. These observations are in agreement with previous reports [54,55]. Finally, the mass loss between 150°C and 600°C (59.4%) agreed with the volatile matter determined in the proximate analysis. 3.3 Uncatalyzed pyrolysis of tire elastomers (polyisoprene, polybutadiene, styrene-butadiene) and waste tire The product distribution during pyrolysis of tire elastomers is shown in Fig. S5. The main product observed from the reaction carried out at 400°C of polybutadiene rubber and styrene-butadiene rubber was 4-vinylcyclohexene with a selectivity of 82% and 55 %, respectively. At the same time, D,L-limonene was the main product from the pyrolysis of polyisoprene rubber, with a selectivity of 76%, followed by isoprene with 23%. A rise in temperature up to 500°C did not significantly alter the observed distribution. Results of the pyrolysis of the waste tire performed between 400 and 500°C are presented in Fig. 3 by grouping species into target groups (see Table S1 for grouping criteria). The most abundant products in this range of temperatures were D,L-limonene (60.4% – 44%), and alkenes (mainly isoprene). These results show that the products detected during the WTP come mainly from polyisoprene rubber decomposition. Increasing the temperature favors the formation of other cycloalkenes from the degradation of the most stable elastomers (BR and SBR), as shown by TGA measurements. According to previous studies, the D,L-limonene is produced by the degradation of polyisoprene rubber by a radical-mediated reaction initiated by β-bond scission concerning the double bonds of the main polymer chain [4,11,56,57]. Then, the allylic radical formed subsequently undergoes an intramolecular cyclization and β-bond scission to form D,L-limonene [4]. Through a similar mechanism, the 4-vinylcyclohexene is the product of homolytic cleavage of the β-bond of the polymeric chains of BR and SBR and the subsequent intramolecular cyclization of the radical chain (Fig. 3). The radical chain of three elastomers can also unzip to the isoprene and 1,3-butadiene monomers. Additionally, a small proportion of BTXs was detected within the reaction products (6.0% - 3.5 %), and p-cymene was below 1% at working temperatures. Cycloalkenes, alkenes, and alkylbenzenes, which are found as waste-tire-pyrolysis reaction by-products, mainly arise from the cracking and aromatization of D,L-limonene and cycloalkenes such as 4-vinlyciclohexene, among others. According to these observations, the reaction map displayed in Fig. 3 is proposed as a basis to discuss how the catalysts can affect the major reaction steps favoring the formation of single-ring aromatics. 3.4 Effect of using TPA-modified CeO2, SiO2, and TiO2 catalysts on product distribution during waste tire pyrolysis The pyrolysis was carried out at 400°C to inspect the role of the catalysts in the product distribution during WTP. For the sake of clarity, the percentages of detected species for TPACe (Fig. 4 a), TPASi (Fig. 4b), and TPATi (Fig. 4c) are presented along with uncatalyzed reaction (Non-Cat), unsupported TPA (TPA), and pristine support (Ce, Si, and Ti) results. This reaction condition was selected because under uncatalyzed pyrolysis, the D,L-limonene was more abundant. Thus, this is the most feasible condition for inspecting the secondary reactions occurring with this species. Results indicated that, regardless of TPA loading, the activity of TPACe for producing D,L-limonene, alkenes, and p-cymene was in the same order as the CeO2-assisted and uncatalyzed experiments (Fig. 4a). These results suggest that TPACe does not affect primary or secondary reactions, which may be explained by the low acidity induced owing to the decomposition of TPA during the catalyst synthesis. An indirect confirmation of the previous statement is the higher capacity of unsupported TPA for promoting aromatization and bond breaking compared to TPACe (see BTX and alkenes % in Fig. 4a). Similar results have been reported using supported TPA catalysts, where catalysts supported on CeO2 exhibited a lower catalytic activity than the other supports [37,52]. Nevertheless, as confirmed in the present work, these studies do not demonstrate that TPA decomposition could cause this activity loss. Still, they report a lower acidity of HPA-CeO2 catalysts, as observed in the present study. Contrary to the TPACe, when TPASi catalysts were used, a decrease in selectivity to D,L-limonene was observed, being higher for the catalyst containing 10% of TPA (Fig. 4b). However, this change did not significantly affect BTX or p-cymene formation compared to the uncatalyzed reaction. Instead, both Si-containing catalysts promoted cracking reactions mainly, leading to the formation of cycloalkenes and alkenes [4], 10%TPASi catalyst being the one that exhibited greater selectivity. These results suggest that the strong interaction of SiO2 with TPA, and the low TPA load, favored a partial decomposition of the heteropoly acid, resulting in a low acidity, hence a low aromatization capacity. When pyrolysis was performed on TPATi catalysts, a remarkable change in the product distribution was observed for both materials, 1TPATi and 10TPATi (Fig. 4c). A very interesting fact was that, under catalyzed conditions, the D,L-limonene was not detected among the reaction products, while the selectivity to p-cymene was significantly favored on 1TPATi (56.3%). This percentage was similar to that of D,L-limonene in the uncatalyzed pyrolysis (60.4%), which indicates that the catalyst promoted secondary reactions in D,L-limonene, leading to the formation of p-cymene. When the 10TPATi catalyst was used, the formation of BTXs (26%), rather than p-cymene (6.5%), was enhanced. In the reaction carried out on unsupported TPA and alone TiO2, p-cymene was only detected for support (23.7%), while on unsupported TPA, its formation was negligible (< 1%). This latter primarily promoted alkene production (limonene decomposition), favored mainly over catalysts with Brønsted acidity due to cracking reactions [58]. Subsequently, when TPA was deposited on TiO2, the activity towards p-cymene formation significantly improved, as demonstrated by a 2.4-fold increment for the 1TPATi catalyst. Concerning BTXs, unsupported TPA had a higher performance (17%) than the uncatalyzed reaction (4.3%) and TiO2 (11.3%). However, in the presence of the 10TPATi catalyst, the selectivity was enhanced to 26%. According to the characterization results, these results are not surprising since the Kegging structure was more preserved on TiO2, resulting in the observed catalytic activity. These results allow concluding that the differences in the formation of p-cymene and BTXs for 1TPATi and 10TPATi are explained by a cooperative effect between the TPA and the TiO2, which is presumably associated with a different balance between Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. 3.5 Role of the nature of acid sites (Lewis or Brønsted) in promoting the formation of p-cymene and BTXs. Reaction pathways The correlation between strong, medium, and weak Brønsted and Lewis acid sites (µmol m−2) and the formation of p-cymene and BTXs during waste tire catalytic pyrolysis was assessed on TPATi catalysts (Fig. 5 a to d), which exhibited a higher selectivity towards these compounds. As seen in Fig. 5b, the catalyst with the highest content of strong BAS (10TPATi = 25.8 µmol gcat −1) favored the formation of BTXs to a greater extent than 1TPATi catalyst and Ti-support. Meanwhile, there was no marked influence of strong BAS on p-cymene formation (Fig. 5a). In contrast, the production of p-cymene was preferentially promoted on the catalyst with the highest proportion of weak LAS (1TPATi = 37.2 µmol gcat −1) (Fig. 5c). However, it is not possible to attribute this last result only to the Lewis acid sites since Ti-support containing the largest amount of weak LAS (52.9 µmol gcat −1) displayed a minor p-cymene selectivity (23.7 %) than catalyst (56.3%) (Fig. 4). This result would demonstrate the participation and synergy between both types of acidity (BAS and LAS). In fact, the selectivity to p-cymene was below 1% for unsupported TPA containing mainly BAS. For this reason, it would be more appropriate to correlate the selectivity towards these compounds with the ratio of LASweak/BASstrong in catalysts containing TPA. For example, for catalyst promoting p-cymene formation (1TPATi), this ratio was ninefold higher than 10TPATi. These results agree with those presented by Tavera-Ruiz et al. [15]. On the other hand, the presence of LAS in the formation of BTXs was less relevant than the presence of strong BAS (Fig. 5d and b). Both 10TPA/TiO2 and unsupported TPA with higher Bronsted acidity were more selective to BTX formation. As previously described [4], p-cymene is mainly formed from D,L-limonene through isomerization reactions of aliphatic terpene driving to isomers: terpinolene and α- and γ-terpinene. Thereafter, these isomers are dehydrogenated, forming the aromatic terpene (p-cymene) (see Scheme 1 ). The route limonene→p-cymene was confirmed by catalytic pyrolysis of polyisoprene rubber (Fig. 6 a). This figure shows that the 1TPATi catalyst promoted p-cymene formation (80.2%) during polyisoprene rubber pyrolysis at the expense of the total D,L-limonene conversion. Meanwhile, although the 10TPATi catalyst showed a high selectivity to p-cymene (56.4%), it is noteworthy that it presented a selectivity to BTXs fourfold that of the 1TPATi catalyst (Fig. 6a). Both catalysts also favored the formation of light alkenes (1,3-butadiene and isoprene) and ethylbenzene from 4-vinyclyclohexene coming from styrene-butadiene and polybutadiene rubbers (Fig. 6b and c, and Scheme 1). In comparison, BTX formation from 4-vinyclyclohexene enhanced over the 10TPATi catalyst at low and high temperatures (Fig. 6b and c). Without a catalyst, secondary reactions were not favored, so mainly products of elastomers pyrolysis (IR, BR and SBR) were D,L-limonene, 4-vinyclyclohexene, and isoprene). The secondary isomerization reactions could involve the participation of Lewis acid sites by forming a carbonium ion or via the allyl route described in previous reports [59–61]. In addition, these reactions can also occur over Brønsted acid sites via the double bond attack, giving rise to olefin protonation, followed by isomerization reactions. Therefore, both types of acid sites (LAS and BAS) would be responsible for the detected isomerization products (Scheme 1). However, the Brønsted acid sites can also induce the breaking of the C-C bond located in the β-position of protonated olefin [62]. This reaction step could contribute to BTX formation from D,L-limonene [4] via scission of the C-C bond of the D,L-limonene ring in the β-position (Scheme 1). Subsequently, isomerization and cyclization reactions would result in some cycloalkenes that have been identified in reaction products (5-ethyl-1,5-dimethyl-1,3-clohexadiene and 1,5,5,6-tetramethyl 1,3-cyclohexadiene). Then, these compounds can undergo dehydrogenation and dealkylation reactions leading to BTX production [4]. The isomerization and dehydrogenation reaction steps would occur on both acid sites (LAS and BAS). In contrast, cracking reaction steps would mainly take place on strong Brønsted acid sites. For this reason, on the catalyst showing a higher number of weak LAS than strong BAS content, isomerization and dehydrogenation reactions leading to p-cymene were favored, while on the catalyst with higher strong BAS content, the formation of BTXs was promoted. 3.6 Kinetic implications of 1TPATi and 10TPATi on BTXs, p-cymene, and solid conversion during waste tire pyrolysis 3.6.1 Kinetics of solid conversion The experiments were carried out under ex situ catalytic operation; thus the solid conversion is not affected by the presence of catalysts. Therefore, the kinetic elucidations presented here are independently discussed for the solid and volatiles, viz. p-cymene and BTXs. The conversion versus time profile for waste tires is given in Fig. 7 , along with the mathematical model that exhibits the best correlation at the three tested temperatures: 400, 450, and 500 °C. Results indicate that the first-order model accurately describes the solid conversion, as confirmed by the R2 = 0.87 and residuals of errors (0.007 – 0.008). Specific deviations from the theoretical trend of this model were found at 500 °C (12 s and 30 s), which is ascribed to the secondary reactions producing cross-linked carbons or inorganic depositions (from additives). Moreover, the (1 – 3) diffusion and the contracting sphere models did not converge in the studied range. The value of the activation energy (105.4 kJ mol−1) indicates that the reaction mechanism governing the solid conversion is consistent with our predictions for reaction scheme and with other authors [63,64]. This global model is an oversimplification of the waste tire pyrolysis mechanism, and it could lead to errors in the estimation of the kinetic triplet, by the compensation between Ea and ko . However, using generalized values of the activation energy in pyrolysis has demonstrated to be crucial for understanding the role of secondary reactions. Therefore, in the following section, we analyze the effect of xTPATi catalysts on the formation of p-cymene and BTXs by secondary reaction steps. 3.6.2 Kinetics of p-cymene and BTXs The temporal yields profiles of p-cymene (Fig. 8 a and c) and BTXs (Fig. 8b and d) depict a similar trend for t < 30 s, regardless the TPA loadings. This result indicates that pyrolysis mechanism is not sensitive to the densities or nature of acid site (LAS or BAS), although these sites will change the product distribution by their kinetic effect on specific reaction steps. For example, the isomerization and dehydrogenation of D,L-limonene in Scheme 1 is promoted by cooperative LAS/BAS sites (1TPATi), while C-C breaking reactions are enhanced on catalysts with a higher proportion of BAS (10TPATi). It is postulated that p-cymene is formed from D,L-limonene via isomerization into two terpinolene intermediates, which are further dehydrogenated (Scheme 1). Therefore, the 0.5-kinetic order obtained for p-cymene on 1TPATi and 10TPATi (Fig. 8a and c) is consistent with this parallel reaction route. Moreover, the value of activation energies for 1TPATi (62.3 kJ mol−1) and 10TPATi (117 kJ mol−1) confirms the kinetic effect of the higher proportion of LAS(medium + strong)/BASstrong in 1TPATi for catalyzing cymene formation. Finally, the deviation from the experimental yields of p-cymene above 30 s indicates that this model is limited to explaining tertiary reactions. On the other hand, the BTX shows a quasi-linear behavior of the normalized yields with reaction time in the whole range of temperatures. This performance is in line with the first reaction order obtained and suggests that these species are not limiting at the catalyst surface. This last point indicates that adsorption-desorption of BTX is quasi-equilibrated, and that primary reactions from polymeric constituents are limiting during pyrolysis. Despite the fact that these results shed light on the catalytic effects of xTPATi during waste tire pyrolysis, further analyses are required for elucidating a mechanistic-based kinetic model. 4 Conclusions Several TPA-containing catalysts were synthesized over different oxides. However, FTIR, RAMAN and 31P MAS NMR characterizations indicate the heteropoly acid is decomposed on CeO2 and to a lesser extent on SiO2. Accordingly, higher yields to target compounds were obtained on more stable catalysts (xTPATi). The analytical experiments demonstrate that waste tire pyrolysis is governed by a complex reaction mechanism involving the primary decomposition of polymers into intermediate platforms (e.g., D,L-limonene and 4-vinylcyclohexene). The presence of xTPATi, regardless of the acid loading, enhanced the formation of p-cymene and BTXs from these intermediates. In the case of 1TPATi the formation of p-cymene (Sp-cymene = 56.3%) was favored over the other target compounds, owing to a cooperative effect between LAS and BAS. Meanwhile, the strong Brønsted acid sites induce the C-C bond scission of the D,L-limonene ring in the β- position, enhancing the formation of BTXs by further aromatization reactions. Accordingly, the formation of aromatics (BTXs) was favored on 10TPATi (SBTX= 26%, with strong BAS content=36.9 μmol gcat −1). The 0.5-order for p-cymene in the power-law kinetics indicates its formation by a parallel reaction route with an activation energy of 62.3 kJ mol−1. The BTXs were kinetically favored on 10TPATi with Ea = 112 kJ mol−1and a first order with respect to the conversion. These results are pioneers in providing insightful information on the use of TPA/TiO2 catalysts for valorizing waste tires via pyrolysis. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of catalysts for upgrading waste tire pyrolysis oils (TPO) into marketable products such as fuels, solvents or fine chemicals is a major challenge. Herein, the effect of CeO2, SiO2, and TiO2 catalysts containing tunsgtophosphoric acid (TPA) on the selectivity to aromatics (benzene, toluene, and xylenes viz. BTXs) and p-cymene was studied for the first time. Modifying TiO2 with 1% and 10% TPA allowed modulating the oxide's acidity, resulting in a ratio of Lewis acid sites and strong Brønsted acid sites that favored the target compound formation. The 1%TPA catalyst enhanced the p-cymene production (Sp-cymene = 56.3%). In contrast, 10%TPA promoted BTX formation (SBTX= 26%) over p-cymene (Sp-cymene = 6.5%) due to its greater content of Brønsted acid sites. The selectivity of SiO2 and CeO2-based catalysts to these aromatic compounds was in the same order as the uncatalyzed reaction. The p-cymene is mainly formed from secondary reactions of isomerization of limonene to other terpenes (terpinolene, α-terpinene, and γ-terpinene) and the subsequent ring dehydrogenation with an activation energy of 62.3 kJ mol−1. The BTXs were kinetically favored on 10%TPATi catalyst with an Ea = 112 kJ mol−1. The study was performed in a fixed bed Pyr-GC/MS system under kinetically controlled regime.
coredata.dc:title: Using tungstophosphoric acid-modified CeO2, TiO2, and SiO2 catalysts to promote secondary reactions leading to aromatics during waste tire pyrolysis
